resources.string: Calorimetry is a lab based on thermochemistry and involves observing heat being transferred throughout reactions. In this particular lab, we will use a coffee cup and a thermometer to determine the heat of solution of a compound, which is the change in energy (kJ) per mole of compound dissolved in water. How will we calculate this? Well, we will pour some of the compound into 100.0 mL of water in a coffee cup, put on the lid, and stir. Using the thermometer, we will be able to see the temperature change of the water as a result of the compound dissociating. We can also assume that the coffee cup is perfectly insulated, meaning that no heat escapes or enters the cup. So, energy gained or lost by the water is equal to the energy lost or gained by the compound. Let\'s get started!

In this lab, we used coffee cup calorimetry to determine the heat of solution of a compound. The temperature change that occurs as certain compounds dissolve can be quite useful. In fact, the two compounds in this lab (calcium chloride and ammonium nitrate) are frequently used in hot or cold packs!
Observe how the water temperature changes as the compound dissolves!
You might want to record this!
Is the dissociation of this compound an exothermic or endothermic reaction?
The reaction is EXOTHERMIC. As calcium chloride dissociates, it releases heat. This heat is absorbed by the surrounding water, causing the temperature to increase.
The reaction is ENDOTHERMIC. As ammonium nitrate dissociates, it absorbs heat. This heat is taken from the surrounding water, causing the temperature to decrease.

Calculate the energy change (in kJ) of the water. Assume that water\'s specific heat is 4.184 J/g°C and its density is 1.00 g/mL. Select the correct sign and be careful of your units! DO NOT ROUND UNTIL THE VERY END!
Select at least 1.00 grams for more accurate results!

The answer is
We can use q = mc∆t, where m = mass of water, c = specific heat of water, and ∆t = final minus initial temperature of water.

Calculate the heat of solution (kJ / mol) of this compound. Calcium chloride\'s molar mass is 110.98 g / mol. Assume that no heat is lost or absorbed by the cup. Select the correct sign and be careful of your units! DO NOT ROUND UNTIL THE VERY END!

Calculate the heat of solution (kJ / mol) of this compound. Ammonium nitrate\'s molar mass is 80.04 g / mol. Assume that no heat is lost or absorbed by the cup. Select the correct sign and be careful of your units! DO NOT ROUND UNTIL THE VERY END!

The answer is
Because we assume that there is only heat transfer between water and the compound,
q of water = -q of the compound's dissolution.

Calculate the percent error (%). The actual heat of solution for calcium chloride is about -82.8 kJ / mol. Also, think about some possible sources of error. DO NOT ROUND UNTIL THE VERY END!
Calculate the percent error (%). The actual heat of solution for ammonium nitrate is about +25.7 kJ / mol. Also, think about some possible sources of error. DO NOT ROUND UNTIL THE VERY END!

The answer is
Using the answer from question 3, percent error = |(							)-(-82.8)) / (-82.8)| * 100%
Percent error =
It is common to get a heat of solution smaller in magnitude than the actual value. This is because some of the heat produced by the compound escapes into the atmosphere or is absorbed by the cup itself. Thus, the water temperature increases less than it should, and you get a smaller calculated heat of solution.

The answer is
Using the answer from question 3, percent error = |(						)-(25.7)) / (25.7)| * 100%
Percent error =
It is common to get a heat of solution smaller in magnitude than the actual value. This is because some of the heat in the atmosphere is absorbed by the water. Thus, the water temperature decreases less than it should, and you get a smaller calculated heat of solution.
